title: Energy - rocket launch with air resistance

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A block sits at rest on a horizontal surface. One end of a spring is attached to the block and the other end of the spring is attached to a wall, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The block is initially at position <math alttext="x equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mstyle></math>, where the spring is at its natural length. The block is then pushed to the left, compressing the spring. The block is released from rest from position <math alttext="x equals negative A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>A</mi></mstyle></math>. All frictional forces are negligible.

Consider the system that consists of the block and the spring. Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> shows an energy bar chart that represents the kinetic energy <math alttext="K" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> and the elastic potential energy <math alttext="U sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></mstyle></math> of the system when the block is released from rest at position <math alttext="x equals negative A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>A</mi></mstyle></math>.

(a) Draw shaded bars that represent <math alttext="K" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> and <math alttext="U sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></mstyle></math> of the system to complete the energy bar charts shown in Figure <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> for when the block is at positions <math alttext="x equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals positive A over 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mstyle></math>.

Shaded regions should start at the solid line that represents zero energy.

Represent any energy that is equal to zero with a distinct line on the zero-energy line.

The relative heights of each shaded region should reflect the magnitudes of the respective energy consistent with the scale used in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

(b)  The mass of the block is \(m\), and the spring constant of the spring is \(k\). Starting with conservation of energy, derive an expression for the speed of the block as it passes through position <math alttext="x equals positive A over 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mstyle></math>. Express your answer in terms of \(m\),\(k\) , <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi>A</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

On Figure <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>, sketch and label a graph of the kinetic energy <math alttext="K" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> and the elastic potential energy <math alttext="U sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></mstyle></math> of the system as a function of the position <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> of the block.
